\chapter{tolerance}
\label{index:tolerance}\label{index:welcome-to-tolerance-s-documentation}\href{http://travis-ci.org/lambdalisue/tolerance}{}\href{https://coveralls.io/r/lambdalisue/tolerance/}{}\href{https://pypi.python.org/pypi/tolerance/}{}\href{https://pypi.python.org/pypi/tolerance/}{}\href{https://pypi.python.org/pypi/tolerance/}{}\href{https://pypi.python.org/pypi/tolerance/}{}\href{https://pypi.python.org/pypi/tolerance/}{}
Do you often write the fail silent codes like below?

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{try}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} do what ever you need...}
    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{foo}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{k}{except}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} fail silently}
    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}
\end{Verbatim}

This kind of codes are often found in \href{https://www.djangoproject.com/}{Django} projects or programs which should
not raise any exceptions in product mode.

\textbf{tolerance} is a function decorator to make a tolerant function; a function
which does not raise any exceptions even there are exceptions.
This concept is quite useful for making stable product or \code{prefer\_int} types
of code described in Usage section.


\section{Features}
\label{index:features}\label{index:django}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Convert a function to a tolerant function

\item {} 
The decorated function returns \code{substitute} (Default is \code{None}) when it
is not callable.
The function returns a ``returned value'' from \code{substitute} function when
it is callable.

\item {} 
Ignoreing exceptions can be specified as a exception class list with
\code{exceptions} argument.

\item {} 
When \code{fail\_silently=False} is passed to the decorated function,
the function does not ignore exceptions (the argument name can be changed
with making switch function via \code{argument\_switch\_generator} function).

\end{itemize}


\section{Installation}
\label{index:installation}
Use \href{https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pip}{pip} like:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\$ pip install tolerance
\end{Verbatim}


\section{Usage}
\label{index:pip}\label{index:usage}
Assume that you need a function which convert a string to an integer when it is
possible.
Without tolerance, you need to write a code like below

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} without tolerance}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{prefer\PYGZus{}int\PYGZus{}withot\PYGZus{}tolerance}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{k}{try}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }        \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{k}{except}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }        \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} fail silently}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }        \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{x}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{prefer\PYGZus{}int\PYGZus{}withot\PYGZus{}tolerance}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{0}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{prefer\PYGZus{}int\PYGZus{}withot\PYGZus{}tolerance}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{0}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{0}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{prefer\PYGZus{}int\PYGZus{}withot\PYGZus{}tolerance}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{zero}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZsq{}zero\PYGZsq{}}
\end{Verbatim}

However, with tolerance, you just need to write a single line code like

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{tolerance} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{tolerate}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{prefer\PYGZus{}int} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{tolerate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k}{lambda} \PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{prefer\PYGZus{}int}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{0}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{prefer\PYGZus{}int}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{0}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{0}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{prefer\PYGZus{}int}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{zero}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZsq{}zero\PYGZsq{}}
\end{Verbatim}

Or you can use \code{tolerate} as a function decorator described in \href{http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0318/}{PEP-318}

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{tolerance} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{tolerate}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n+nd}{@tolerate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k}{lambda} \PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{prefer\PYGZus{}int\PYGZus{}318}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{prefer\PYGZus{}int\PYGZus{}318}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{0}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{prefer\PYGZus{}int\PYGZus{}318}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{0}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{0}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{prefer\PYGZus{}int\PYGZus{}318}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{zero}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZsq{}zero\PYGZsq{}}
\end{Verbatim}

The example codes above  specify \code{substitute} argument of \code{tolerate}
function to specify the returning value when the function has failed (
\code{lambda x: x} part).
\code{tolerate} function takes several arguments to configure the function
behavior.
These arguments are explained in Case study and detailed in API documentation.


\section{Case study}
\label{index:case-study}\label{index:pep-318}

\subsection{Q. How can I return the default value when the function fail?}
\label{index:q-how-can-i-return-the-default-value-when-the-function-fail}\begin{enumerate}
\item {} 
Use \code{substitute} argument to specify the default value like

\end{enumerate}

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{tolerance} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{tolerate}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n+nd}{@tolerate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{substitute}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{foo}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{raise\PYGZus{}exception}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{k}{raise} \PYG{n+ne}{Exception}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{raise\PYGZus{}exception}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZsq{}foo\PYGZsq{}}
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{Q. How can I change the default value depends on passed arguments?}
\label{index:q-how-can-i-change-the-default-value-depends-on-passed-arguments}\begin{enumerate}
\item {} 
Specify \code{substitute} argument as a function

\end{enumerate}

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{tolerance} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{tolerate}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{substitute\PYGZus{}function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{args}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{kwargs}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} do what ever you need, this example simply return 1st argument}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{args}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n+nd}{@tolerate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{substitute}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{substitute\PYGZus{}function}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{raise\PYGZus{}exception}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{args}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{k}{raise} \PYG{n+ne}{Exception}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{raise\PYGZus{}exception}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{bar}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{hoge}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZsq{}bar\PYGZsq{}}
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{Q. How can I make the function to ignore only several exceptions?}
\label{index:q-how-can-i-make-the-function-to-ignore-only-several-exceptions}\begin{enumerate}
\item {} 
Use \code{exceptions} argument to specify exceptions which will be ignored.

\end{enumerate}

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{tolerance} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{tolerate}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{exceptions\PYGZus{}ignored} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{(}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{n+ne}{AttributeError}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{n+ne}{ValueError}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n+nd}{@tolerate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{exceptions}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{exceptions\PYGZus{}ignored}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{raise\PYGZus{}exception}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{x} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }        \PYG{k}{raise} \PYG{n+ne}{AttributeError}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{k}{elif} \PYG{n}{x} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }        \PYG{k}{raise} \PYG{n+ne}{ValueError}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{k}{else}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }        \PYG{k}{raise} \PYG{n+ne}{KeyError}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{raise\PYGZus{}exception}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o+ow}{is} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{None}
\PYG{g+go}{True}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{raise\PYGZus{}exception}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o+ow}{is} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{None}
\PYG{g+go}{True}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{raise\PYGZus{}exception}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gt}{Traceback (most recent call last):}

\subsection{Q. How can I disable ignoreing exceptions in the decorated function?}
\label{index:q-how-can-i-disable-ignoreing-exceptions-in-the-decorated-function}\begin{enumerate}
\item {} 
Pass \code{fail\_silently=False} to the decorated function.

\end{enumerate}

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{tolerance} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{tolerate}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n+nd}{@tolerate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{raise\PYGZus{}exception}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{k}{raise} \PYG{n+ne}{KeyError}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{raise\PYGZus{}exception}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o+ow}{is} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{None}
\PYG{g+go}{True}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{raise\PYGZus{}exception}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{fail\PYGZus{}silently}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{False}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gt}{Traceback (most recent call last):}
    \PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}
\PYG{g+gr}{KeyError}
\end{Verbatim}

You can change the attribute name with specifing new switch function.
It will be explained below.


\subsection{Q. How can I disable ignoreing exceptions globally?}

\end{enumerate}

\chapter{How to run the tests}
\label{index:how-to-run-the-tests}\begin{enumerate}
\item {} 
Install requirement packages with \code{requirements-test.txt}:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\$ pip install -r requirements-test
\end{Verbatim}

\item {} 
Run tests with \code{nosetests} command provided by \href{https://nose.readthedocs.org/en/latest/index.html}{nose} (it is automatically
installed via \code{requirements-test.txt})
\begin{quote}

\$ nosetests
\end{quote}

\end{enumerate}

All configuration for running tests can be found at \code{{[}nosetests{]}} section of
\code{setup.cfg} file.


\chapter{API documents}
\label{index:api-documents}\label{index:nose}

\section{tolerance Package}
\label{tolerance:tolerance-package}\label{tolerance::doc}

\subsection{\texttt{tolerance} Package}
\label{tolerance:id1}\phantomsection\label{tolerance:module-tolerance}\index{tolerance (module)}
tolerance

tolerance is a function decorator to make a tolerant function; a function
which does not raise any exceptions even there are exceptions.
This concept is quite useful for making stable product or \code{prefer\_int} types
of code described in Usage section.
\index{tolerate() (in module tolerance)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{tolerance:tolerance.tolerate}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{tolerance.}\bfcode{tolerate}}{\emph{substitute=None}, \emph{exceptions=None}, \emph{switch=\textless{}function switch\_function at 0x2b0f050\textgreater{}}}{}
A function decorator which makes a function fail silently

To disable fail silently in a decorated function, specify
\code{fail\_silently=False}.
To disable fail silenlty in decorated functions globally, specify
\code{tolerate.disabled}.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters }] \leavevmode
\textbf{fn} : function
\begin{quote}

A function which will be decorated.
\end{quote}

\textbf{substitute} : function or returning value
\begin{quote}

A function used instead of \code{fn} or returning value
when \code{fn} failed.
\end{quote}

\textbf{exceptions} : list of exceptions or None
\begin{quote}

A list of exception classes or None. 
If exceptions is specified, ignore exceptions only listed in this
parameter and raise exception if the exception is not listed.
\end{quote}

\textbf{switch} : function or None
\begin{quote}

A switch function which determine whether silent the function failar.
The function receive \code{*args} and \code{**kwargs} which will specified
to \code{fn} and should return status (bool), args, and kwargs.
If the function return \code{False} then agggressive decorated function
worked as normal function (raise exception when there is exception).
Default switch function is generated by
{\hyperref[tolerance:tolerance.argument_switch_generator]{\code{argument\_switch\_generator()}}} with
\code{argument\_switch\_generator('fail\_silently')}
so if \code{fail\_silently=False} is specified to the function, the function
works as noramlly.
\end{quote}

\item[{Returns }] \leavevmode
\textbf{function} :
\begin{quote}

A decorated function
\end{quote}

\end{description}\end{quote}
\paragraph{Examples}

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} use tolerate as a function wrapper}

\index{argument\_switch\_generator() (in module tolerance)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{tolerance:tolerance.argument_switch_generator}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{tolerance.}\bfcode{argument\_switch\_generator}}{\emph{argument\_name}, \emph{default=True}, \emph{reverse=False}, \emph{keep=False}}{}
Create switch function which return the status from specified named argument
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters }] \leavevmode
\textbf{argument\_name} : string
\begin{quote}

An argument name which is used to judge the status
\end{quote}

\textbf{default} : boolean
\begin{quote}

A default value of this switch function.
It is used when specifid \code{**kwargs} does not have named argument
\end{quote}

\textbf{reverse} : boolean
\begin{quote}

Reverse the status (Default: \code{False})
\end{quote}

\textbf{keep} : boolean
\begin{quote}

If it is \code{True}, keep named argument in \code{**kwargs}.
\end{quote}

\item[{Returns }] \leavevmode
\textbf{function} :
\begin{quote}

A switch function which return status, args, and kwargs respectively.
\end{quote}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\subsection{\texttt{decorators} Module}
\label{tolerance:module-tolerance.decorators}\label{tolerance:decorators-module}\index{tolerance.decorators (module)}
tolerance decorator module
\index{DEFAULT\_TOLERATE\_SWITCH() (in module tolerance.decorators)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{tolerance:tolerance.decorators.DEFAULT_TOLERATE_SWITCH}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{tolerance.decorators.}\bfcode{DEFAULT\_TOLERATE\_SWITCH}}{\emph{*args}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Default tolerate switch function

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{tolerate() (in module tolerance.decorators)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{tolerance:tolerance.decorators.tolerate}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{tolerance.decorators.}\bfcode{tolerate}}{\emph{substitute=None}, \emph{exceptions=None}, \emph{switch=\textless{}function switch\_function at 0x2b0f050\textgreater{}}}{}
A function decorator which makes a function fail silently

To disable fail silently in a decorated function, specify
\code{fail\_silently=False}.
To disable fail silenlty in decorated functions globally, specify
\code{tolerate.disabled}.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters }] \leavevmode
\textbf{fn} : function
\begin{quote}

A function which will be decorated.
\end{quote}

\textbf{substitute} : function or returning value
\begin{quote}

A function used instead of \code{fn} or returning value
when \code{fn} failed.
\end{quote}

\textbf{exceptions} : list of exceptions or None
\begin{quote}

A list of exception classes or None. 
If exceptions is specified, ignore exceptions only listed in this
parameter and raise exception if the exception is not listed.
\end{quote}

\textbf{switch} : function or None
\begin{quote}

A switch function which determine whether silent the function failar.
The function receive \code{*args} and \code{**kwargs} which will specified
to \code{fn} and should return status (bool), args, and kwargs.
If the function return \code{False} then agggressive decorated function
worked as normal function (raise exception when there is exception).
Default switch function is generated by
\code{argument\_switch\_generator()} with
\code{argument\_switch\_generator('fail\_silently')}
so if \code{fail\_silently=False} is specified to the function, the function
works as noramlly.
\end{quote}

\item[{Returns }] \leavevmode
\textbf{function} :
\begin{quote}

A decorated function
\end{quote}

\end{description}\end{quote}
\paragraph{Examples}

\subsection{\texttt{utils} Module}
\label{tolerance:module-tolerance.utils}\label{tolerance:utils-module}\index{tolerance.utils (module)}
tolerance utility module
\index{argument\_switch\_generator() (in module tolerance.utils)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{tolerance:tolerance.utils.argument_switch_generator}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{tolerance.utils.}\bfcode{argument\_switch\_generator}}{\emph{argument\_name}, \emph{default=True}, \emph{reverse=False}, \emph{keep=False}}{}
Create switch function which return the status from specified named argument
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters }] \leavevmode
\textbf{argument\_name} : string
\begin{quote}

An argument name which is used to judge the status
\end{quote}

\textbf{default} : boolean
\begin{quote}

A default value of this switch function.
It is used when specifid \code{**kwargs} does not have named argument
\end{quote}

\textbf{reverse} : boolean
\begin{quote}

Reverse the status (Default: \code{False})
\end{quote}

\textbf{keep} : boolean
\begin{quote}

If it is \code{True}, keep named argument in \code{**kwargs}.
\end{quote}

\item[{Returns }] \leavevmode
\textbf{function} :
\begin{quote}

A switch function which return status, args, and kwargs respectively.
\end{quote}

\end{description}\end{quote}
\paragraph{Examples}
